section.title: Working with editors: opening, adding/deleting/renaming items, commenting, adding descriptions, extracting and replacing, reverting changes
section.para: The editors for Test Cases, Test Suites and Test Jobs all let you work in a similar way in the ITE. When you are working in an editor, the Properties View, Data Sets View and Component Names View on the right hand side of the screen contain information about the selected item.

section.title: Opening items in editors
section.para:
To open an existing Test Case, Test Suite or Test Job in an editor, you can either double-click the item you want to open in its browser or you can select:
Open With-->... Editor
from the context-sensitive menu for the item.

para.para: If you double-click on an item in a browser that is reused in another item (e.g. you double-click a Test Case that is reused in another Test Case), the editor for its direct parent will open, and the item you double-clicked is selected.

section.para: You can also open an existing Test Case without having to select it from the Test Case Browser using the Open Test Case dialog ().

section.title: Adding items to editors
section.para: You can add (reference) Test Cases in other Test Cases and in Test Suites. You can also add (reference) Test Suites in Test Jobs.
To add items to an editor:

listitem.para: Open the editor by double-clicking the item you want to add things to.
You can now:
Add items via drag and drop from the browser into the editor:
Test Cases: Test Cases can be added to other Test Cases and Test Suites by selecting the Test Case from the Test Case Browser and dragging it into the editor.
Test Suites: Test Suites can be referenced in Test Jobs by selecting the Test Suite to reference from the Test Suite Browser and dragging it into the Test Job Editor.

para.para: Once you have added a Test Suite to a Test Job, you must enter the AUT ID for the AUT to be tested in the Properties View.

listitem.para:
For Test Cases, you can also use the Reference Existing Test Case dialog. Using the context-sensitive menu in the editor, select:
Reference Existing Test Case

para.para: You can also press »ENTER« in the editor to open the Reference Existing Test Case dialog.

listitem.para: Using this dialog (), you can choose a Test Case or Test Cases to add to the editor. You can filter in through the dialog using the field at the top. Use star * as a wild card.

section.para: Items you reference in editors are marked with a small arrow to show that they are reused (referenced) here. The name of the item is contained in angled brackets (< >) to show that it is the same name that you used when you specified the Test Case. Items can be renamed to reflect their particular use in this editor ().

para.para: You can’t add items which would cause an infinite loop.

listitem.para: Open the item from which you want to delete other items in the editor
Right-click on the item(s) to be deleted (use »CTRL« to select multiple items) and select ”Delete” from the context-sensitive menu.
You can also use »DELETE« to delete items.
Save the changes in the editor.

section.title: Renaming items in editors
section.para: You can rename items referenced in Test Cases, Test Suites and Test Jobs.

listitem.para: Open the editor containing the items you want to rename.
Select the item you want to rename in the editor.
In the Properties View, enter the new name for the item in the Reference Name field at the top of the Properties View.
Save the editor.

The angled brackets from the item you just edited will disappear from the name in the editor. This indicates that the item has been renamed here. You will still see the original item name behind the new name in brackets. In the preferences, you can opt not to see the original name when you have renamed an item ().
The original item in the browser still has its original name. The referenced item you just renamed will keep its new name even if you rename the original item.

If you want to reset the original specification name, empty the Reference Name field and save the editor. The item will redisplay the angled brackets and will have the same name as the specification name.

section.title: Adding comments to items in editors
section.para: You can add comments to items via the editor for an item. You can add comments to the item itself, or to other items used in it.

listitem.para: Open the editor for the item you want to add comments to.
Enter a comment in the comment field in the Properties View.
Save the changes

Comments can be overwritten when an item is reused.
You can see the comment for a Test Case when you hover over it in the Test Case Browser or the Test Suite Browser or in the search results view.

para.para: You can also add comments to categories using the context-menu in the browser () and to the Project itself via the Project properties ().

section.title: Adding descriptions to items in editors
section.para: Descriptions are longer pieces of text that provide information about nodes in your tests. You can add descriptions in the ITE to Test Cases, Test Suites and Test Jobs via the editor for these items. You can add descriptions to the item itself, or to other items used in it.

listitem.para: Open the editor containing the item you want to add a description to.
Select the item you want to add, and select from the context-sensitive menu:

In the dialog that opens, you can enter text in the upper field. The text you enter can use the syntax of various markup languages (e.g. TracWiki, MediaWiki). You can set the language for your Project in the Project properties ().
In the lower field, you can see the preview of the text as it will appear in the description view. The preview is updated after a short pause in typing.
Click "OK" to close the dialog. You will see the description you have entered in the description view. If the description view is not open, you can open it by selecting:
Window --> Show View--> Description
The changes to your descriptions are saved when you save the editor.

You can add a description for the original specification of a Test Case or a Test Suite, and also at places where a Test Case or Test Suite has been reused. You can add a new description to overwrite an existing one when you reuse an item.
Descriptions are not displayed in test results.

section.title: Adding Task IDs to items in editors
section.para: You can add a Task ID to a Test Case, Test Suite or Test Job in the relevant editor. You can add a task ID to the item itself, but not to other items used in it (unless you edit them in their own editor).

listitem.para: Open the editor for the item you want to add a task ID to.
Enter a task ID in the Task ID field in the Properties View.
Save the changes
Task IDs cannot be overwritten when an item is reused.

section.title: Commenting out items in editors
section.para: In the Test Case Editor and the Test Suite Editor, you can deactivate and reactivate Test Cases and Test Steps.

listitem.para:
Select the Test Steps or Test Cases you want to deactivate and select:
Set as active / inactive
from the context menu.
You can also use »CTRL+7« to toggle the items as active or inactive.
The items you selected will be set as inactive. They are shown with green text and the sign // before the Test Case or Test Step name.
Any inactive items are not considered in Test Suite validation, nor are they executed during a test run.

You can reactivate the items by selecting:
Set as active / inactive
from the context menu.

section.title: Extracting Test Cases from editors: Refactoring
section.para: You can extract Test Cases from other Test Cases and from Test Suites. This lets you create keywords even after you have started specifying.

listitem.para: Open the Test Case Editor or Test Suite Editor by double-clicking on the Test Case or Test Suite you want to edit.
Select the Test Cases you want to extract by single-clicking them. Use »CTRL« to select more than one item.

Right-click in the editor and select:
Refactor-->Extract Test Case.
When prompted, enter a name for the new Test Case.
The Test Cases you selected will be extracted into this new Test Case.

The extracted Test Case appears as a reused Test Case in the current editor. It is marked with a small arrow to show that it is reused, and the Test Case name is in angled brackets (< >) to show that it is the same as the specification name.
The Test Case you just created is also visible in the Test Case Browser.

para.para: Use this feature when you realize that you are planning on reusing one or more Test Cases for the same or a similar action again. You will save yourself time in test creation and maintenance.

section.title: Replacing Test Cases in editors: Refactoring
section.para: You can replace one or more Test Cases in an editor with another Test Case from your library of Test Cases. This is useful if you have created a module to replace one or more Test Cases and you want to be guided through the replacement process.

para.para: To replace a specific Test Case at all / multiple places where it has been reused, use the option available in the Search Result View ().

listitem.para: Open the Test Case Editor or Test Suite Editor by double-clicking on the Test Case or Test Suite you want to edit.
Select the Test Cases you want to replace by single-clicking them. Use »CTRL« to select more than one item.

Right-click in the editor and select:
Refactor-->Replace with Test Case.
The first page of a wizard appears in which you can replace selected the Test Cases in a series of steps.

para.para: You may only replace single Test Cases which neither have multiple data sets nor central test data / Excel files as data.

listitem.para: On the first page of the wizard (), you can select a new Test Case to replace the selected Test Cases.
Browse to and select the Test Case you want to add to the editor.
Click ”Next” to match the component names for the old and new Test Cases, or click ”Finish” to replace the selected Test Cases with the bare new Test Case, without any component names transferred.
On the second page of the wizard (), you can see an overview of component names for the replacement.

On the left-hand side you can see any component names that were entered for the Test Cases to be replaced. If the component names were propagated (), you will see a small yellow arrow on the component name icon.
If the old Test Cases contained no component names, then you will see the text no component names.
On the right-hand side, you can see the Component Names View, which shows any component names that are required by the new Test Case.

Use this dialog to transfer any component names from the old Test Cases to the new Test Cases. You can enter component names, or you can leave the new component names as they are. You can also set the checkbox in the Component Names View to propagate the name to the next Test Case in the hierarchy.

Once you have transferred the component names, you can click ”Next” to add further information or you can click ”Finish” to replace the selected Test Cases with the new Test Case and the selected component names.
On the final page of the wizard, you can enter a Test Case reference name and a comment for the new Test Case.
Once you have entered a name and/or a comment, you can click ”Finish” to complete the replacement.

section.para: Once you have replaced the Test Case, you must manually adapt the parameters for the new Test Case.

section.title: Saving Test Cases from an editor as a new Test Case
section.para: You can save selected Test Cases from other Test Cases and from Test Suites. This lets you create a new keyword that contains the selected modules without having to manually find them and reuse them.

listitem.para: Open the Test Case Editor or Test Suite Editor by double-clicking on the Test Case or Test Suite you want to edit.
Select the Test Cases you want to save into the new Test Case by single-clicking them. Use »CTRL« to select more than one item.

Right-click in the editor and select:
Refactor-->Save as new....
When prompted, enter a name for the new Test Case.
A new Test Case will be created containing the Test Cases you selected, with the data and component names they used in the current editor.
The Test Case you just created is visible in the Test Case Browser.

para.para: Use this feature if you have created reusable Test Cases that are correctly modularized, but you require them again (e.g. prerequisites for another Test Case). If the sequence of actions you require is a recurring logical sequence (e.g. enter username, enter password, then click OK for a login dialog), then we strongly recommend using the Extract function () instead. This will give you one reusable module, and therefore one central place to make any changes should this sequence change.

section.title: Reverting changes in an editor
section.para: You can revert an editor you are working in to the state of the last save.

listitem.para:
In the editor you are in, right-click and select:
Revert changes
from the context sensitive menu.
Confirm that you want to revert the changes when prompted.
The editor will be reverted. Any changes you have made since the last save will be lost.
